schema_place.name: Mount Flume
schema_place.description: Mount Flume is a 4,328 foot peak in New Hampshire offering hiking trails with scenic views.

review.reviewBody: Stunning views from the top, worth the climb!
Flume Slide Trail was challenging but rewarding.
Loved the scenery and wildflowers along the trail.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Mount Flume?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Mount Flume take 3-5 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 6.2 miles with Hard difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Mount Flume hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Mount Flume is rated Hard. At 4,328 feet, expect challenging terrain above treeline with potential for rapid weather changes. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Mount Flume?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Mount Flume. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Mount Flume?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Flume Slide Trail, offering Trail to Mount Flume summit..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Mount Flume?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Mount Flume is late May through October. Summer and fall offer the best conditions, though expect crowds on weekends. Winter hiking requires specialized gear and experience.

page_content.description:
At 4,328 feet, Mount Flume ranks among New Hampshire's celebrated 4000-Footers—a collection of 48 peaks that challenge and inspire hikers throughout the Northeast. This hard summit offers a quintessential White Mountain experience.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Flume Slide Trail**, covers 6.2 miles and is rated Hard. Trail to Mount Flume summit.

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** Mount Liberty lies just 0.9 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.conditions: Muddy trails, snow above 3000ft until May
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.conditions: Peak foliage late Sept, early snow possible in October
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.conditions: Full winter conditions, extreme cold and wind above treeline
winter.tips: Winter hiking requires specialized skills and gear. Never hike alone. Check avalanche conditions for steeper terrain.

current_hazards: ⚠️ ALPINE ZONE: Weather changes rapidly. Turn back if conditions deteriorate.
Winter conditions in effect - full mountaineering gear required
Hypothermia risk - temperatures 20-40°F colder at summit
Trail markers may be buried under snow
